title: directory: Fix max call in mtimelevel
body:
Pylint flagged a nested max call as redundant but it was a false positive. However, the nested max call materialized a generator as a list and prepended `-1` because the function errors on an empty argument. Instead of nesting a max call we can drop the nesting and prepend the current value instead of passing it as a separate argument.

Fixes #2812

title: get_executables: Use platform instead of reading /proc
body:
Not every system has a `/proc` file system. We could catch the error but it is simpler to check `platform.release()`. This string contains `WSL2` for WSL version 2 but the only common substring for version 1 is lower case `microsoft`. On Windows this string should simply contain a major version number and not include that substring.

Fixes #2815

title: Too many colors
body:
Some terminals do not support the number of color pairs we use. Python's
curses module used to throw a curses.error for this case but in Python
3.10 this was changed to ValueError.

Approximating the pair with the closest one that is already set up might
be a viable fix but very few terminals are so limited in their color
support and it might make things subtly off but hard to put your finger
on. So we are falling back to the default white on black pair.

Fixes #2752
Fixes #2761
Fixes #2800

title: Fix Python 2 support related to Subprocess
body:
Accidentally introduced names that were introduced in Python 3. TimeoutExpired inherits from SubprocessError, which isn't in Python2 either, which inherits from Exception. Way too broad but not really another option.

DEVNULL was also introduced to the subprocess module later. Passing in `os.devnull` should be more or less equivalent in behavior.

title: NamedTemporaryFile ignores IMAGE_CACHE_DIRECTORY
body:
Previously thumbnails was done in scope.sh here,

https://github.com/ranger/ranger/blob/master/ranger/data/scope.sh#L171

This attempted to take into account IMAGE_CACHE_PATH

Now that code seems to be here,

https://github.com/ranger/ranger/blob/391f061cb0b0cfa8266c0651f2a6d948f22e01dd/ranger/ext/img_display.py#L669

And the problem with this is that there is no ability to set the cache directory so they're all recorded to `/tmp`. **At the very least. you should store them in a directory in tmp**. But ideally, we'd be able to configure the cache directory. The function you're using, [`NamedTemporaryFile`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/tempfile.html) permits that by setting the `dir` argument.

title: img_display: Restore cleanup of Kitty tempfiles
body:
Kitty version 0.26.0 stopped removing temporary files used in the Kitty Image Protocol unless their full path contains the string "tty-graphics-protocol," so we need to adapt to the new behavior.

By using a subdirectory of the directory used for temporary files with the appropriate name, Kitty should again delete the temporary PNGs we generate. An added benefit of using a subdirectory is avoiding cluttering up the directory for temporary files. This subdirectory is not cleaned up by Ranger and will remain as an empty directory (if previews work correctly) until removed by other means.

Fixes #2699

title: Ranger crashes if the path for a saved tab no longer exists
body: We should report this to the user, potentially with a dialog for whether to keep that saved tab or not.

title: gui/color: Catch curses.init_pair ValueError
body:
I cannot reproduce the original issue so I only included the fix as suggested by @narapez.

I'd like to add a user-visible notification so users are made aware of their colorscheme not working as intended. But this is hard to implement without being able to test.

title: kitty image preview temporary files not automatically removed after viewing on kitty 0.26.0+
body:
<!--
    Thank you for contributing to ranger by opening this issue.
    Please check through this list, so you can be as helpful as possible:

    1. Was this issue already reported?  Please do a quick search.
    2. Maybe the problem is solved in the current master branch already?
       Simply clone ranger's git repository and run ./ranger.py to find out.
    3. Provide all the relevant information, as outlined in this template.
       Feel free to remove any sections you don't need.
-->

#### Runtime Environment
<!-- Retrieve Python/ranger version and locale with `ranger --version` -->
- Operating system and version: Arch Linux
- Terminal emulator and version: kitty 0.26.2
- Python version: 3.9.12 (05fbe3aa5b0845e6c37239768aa455451aa5faba, Aug 10 2022, 21:31:33) [PyPy 7.3.9 with GCC 12.1.1 20220730]
- Ranger version/commit: 1.9.3
- Locale: en_AU.UTF-8

#### Current Behavior
Temporary files generated for image previews in kitty are never deleted.

#### Expected Behavior
Temporary files generated for image previews in kitty should be automatically deleted after being read by the terminal.

#### Context
<!-- How has this issue affected you?  What are you trying to accomplish? -->
After browsing some amount of images in ranger my `/tmp` folder fills up, most notably causing image previews to stop working. This can temporarily be resolved by deleting the generated files.
kitty 0.26.0 ([changelog](https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/changelog)) introduces a new restriction on deletion of temporary files, which is the cause of the issue:
> - Graphics protocol: Only delete temp files if they have the string `tty-graphics-protocol` in their file paths. This prevents deletion of arbitrary files in `/tmp`.

#### Possible Solutions
The source of the issue is this line:
https://github.com/ranger/ranger/blob/fcf44f6f12506fa0096cb6468de6a2706bbfaf51/ranger/ext/img_display.py#L669
I suggest changing `prefix='ranger_thumb_'` to `prefix='tty-graphics-protocol-'` or similar.

#### Steps to reproduce
1. Open ranger in kitty 0.26.0 or newer
2. set `preview_files=true`, `preview_images=true` and `preview_images_method=kitty`
3. Browse through images (/anything that has an image preview?)
4. Run out of space in `/tmp`

title: Fix image display for palette images with transparency
body:
Even if image is not in RGB or RGBA format, it could still contain
transparency information.

I used the "transparency" key in the image info dict, see documentation here: https://pillow.readthedocs.io/en/stable/handbook/image-file-formats.html
Basically this key only exists for some formats in some modes, when the image contains transparency. I didn't test any formats besides a rudimentary test of palette mode .png; this change may also affect .eps, .gif, .gd, .xpm.

title: ranger with `update_title` set crashes in terminal emulators that don't support/advertise statusline capabilities
body:
#### Runtime Environment

```
$ ranger --version
ranger version: ranger 1.9.3
Python version: 3.10.2 (main, Jan 15 2022, 19:56:27) [GCC 11.1.0]
Locale: en_US.UTF-8
```

- Operating system and version: Up-to-date archlinux
- Terminal emulator and version: `foot version: 1.11.0 +pgo +ime +graphemes -assertions`

#### Current Behavior

If using a terminal emulator that does not support updating the window title (no statusline capabilities in terminfo), and `rc.conf` contains `set update_title true`, ranger does not start (crash).

#### Expected Behavior

Ranger should not crash but print a warning and not update the window title.

#### Context

AIUI whether a terminal emulator supports updating the window title or not is determined by the respective terminfo file. On archlinux and voidlinux, the regular `foot` terminfo is provided by ncurses (v6.3), but [currently lacks statusline capabilities](https://codeberg.org/dnkl/foot/issues/872) (this will be fixed in the next ncurses release according to the linked issue). This is how I found the issue.

#### Possible Solutions

On archlinux and voidlinux, install `foot-terminfo`, which installs foot's own terminfo as `foot-extra`. Then set `term=foot-extra` in `foot.ini` (or run foot with `--term=foot-extra`). Then foot advertises statusline capabilities correctly and ranger updates the window title, and does not crash.

#### Steps to reproduce

1. Use a terminal emulator that does not support updating the window title (no statusline capabilities in terminfo).
2. `set update_title true` in `rc.conf`
3. start ranger

#### Traceback

```
ranger version: ranger 1.9.3
Python version: 3.10.2 (main, Jan 15 2022, 19:56:27) [GCC 11.1.0]
Locale: en_US.UTF-8
Current file: '/home/camoz/bin'

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ranger/core/main.py", line 201, in main
    fm.loop()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ranger/core/fm.py", line 377, in loop
    ui.redraw()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/site-packages/ranger/gui/ui.py", line 333, in redraw

AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'decode'


```

title: Drop open23
body: I messed up when creating this compatibility wrapper. I originally wanted to avoid `io.open` because of performance implications but when taking into account all the consequences of wrapping properly it doesn't seem worth the extra effort since that function exists and does more than we need it to, supporting all the arguments of Python 3 `open()`, for instance.

title: ui: Fix crash when TMUX not in environment
body:
Made a mistake when merging #2201. If the "TMUX" key isn't in the
environment dictionary we'll get a KeyError. Providing an empty string
default should fix the problem.

I applied the same logic to the check for screen because TERM isn't
guaranteed to be in the environment either, though this verges os
malicious.

title: Process forking was broken when satisfying pylint's consider-using-with
body:
I've reverted the relevant with-statement transformations.

I also noticed that `with Popen():` isn't compatible with Python 2 so I added a wrapper and a pylint check to fix it and make sure it doesn't happen again.

title: commands: Change precedence of clipboard managers
body:
`wl-copy` used to take precedence over `xclip` and `xsel` but this can
cause problems. So let's try the other way around, maybe Wayland users
are less likely to have `xclip` and `xsel` installed than the other way
around.

Fixes #1861

title: Clickable preview
body:
A regression when implementing preview scrolling meant that clicking the preview no longer opens files.

I have fixed this regression but changed the original behavior to require a right click because the left click caused plenty of frustration by accidentally opening files when focusing the terminal window.

title: [Regression]: Clicking in the preview column no longer opens files
body:
This is a regression introduced when implementing the preview scrolling feature.
I didn't notice this because I don't rely on the feature and in hindsight I realize I did stop accidentally opening files whenever I switched to the ranger window using a mouse.

So I propose to bring back the feature but require a right click rather than a left click to make accidental file opening unlikely.

title: Incorrect handling of the file URI scheme
body:
#### Runtime Environment

- Operating system and version: Fedora 33
- Terminal emulator and version: rxvt-unicode v9.22
- Python version: 3.9.1
- Ranger version: 1.9.3
- Locale: en_US.UTF-8

#### Current Behavior

ranger does not open any path presented as a proper file URI, i.e., a path with a form like `file:///path/to/dir` as described in [RFC 8089](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc8089). Instead, an error message with the text *"Inaccessible paths"* is printed.

```bash
$ ranger file:///home/trk/Documents/
Inaccessible paths: home/trk/Documents/
```

However, ranger does open such an URI if there are three slashes in the scheme prefix, like so: `file:////path/to/dir`. It is to be noted that this is not the correct form of a file URI.

#### Expected Behavior

ranger opens any file URI correctly.

#### Context

I first encountered this issue when using the Rider IDE's *"Show in ranger"* option. Selecting it opened the project directory in my browser instead of ranger, pointing to a file URI for the directory.

#### Steps to reproduce

Start ranger, giving it a file URI as a path argument:
```bash
$ ranger file:///usr/bin/
```

title: shell_automatic_cd example file has misnamed bind function
body:
This a relatively simple issue. [shell_automatic_cd](https://github.com/ranger/ranger/blob/master/examples/shell_automatic_cd.sh) is a small shell script to be ```source```ed or included in a ```.bashrc``` to make a ```ranger_cd``` command that runs ranger and, upon quiting, ```cd```s the user into the directory ```ranger``` was last in. This works fine. The script also adds a keybinding to call this command on Ctrl + o, but it mistakenly calls ```ranger-cd``` instead of ```ranger_cd```. Changing the final line from 
```
bind '"\C-o":"ranger-cd\C-m"'
```
to 
```
bind '"\C-o":"ranger_cd\C-m"'
```
fixes the problem on my system.

title: Ranger crashes on right click when window is small

#### Runtime Environment
<!-- Retrieve Python/ranger version and locale with `ranger --version` -->
- Operating system and version: Manjaro 5.4.85
- Terminal emulator and version: Konsole 20.12.0
- Python version: 3.9.1
- Ranger version/commit: ranger-master
- Locale: en_CA.UTF-8

#### Current Behavior
When the terminal where ranger is running is small, clicking on a folder other than the focused folder causes ranger to crash.

#### Expected Behavior
Ranger should register the click and select the clicked folder.

#### Context
I often use ranger in a small terminal window alongside lots of others. This bug led me to accidentally quit out of ranger multiple times and require me to navigate back to where I was before to continue my work.

#### Possible Solutions
Introduce an if statement in tab.py that only changes the pointed object if self.thisdir.files is not none. I have submitted a pull request which applies this fix.

#### Steps to reproduce
1. Open ranger in a small terminal window.
2. Right click on anything other than the focused folder.

title: Fix mimetypes initialization #1744
body:
<!-- Provide a descriptive summary of the changes in the title above -->

#### ISSUE TYPE
<!-- Pick relevant types and delete the rest -->
- Bug fix

#### CHECKLIST
<!-- All [REQUIRED] requisites need to be fulfilled -->

- [X] The `CONTRIBUTING` document has been read **[REQUIRED]**
- [X] All changes follow the code style **[REQUIRED]**
- [X] All new and existing tests pass **[REQUIRED]**
- [ ] Changes require config files to be updated
    - [ ] Config files have been updated
- [ ] Changes require documentation to be updated
    - [ ] Documentation has been updated
- [ ] Changes require tests to be updated
    - [ ] Tests have been updated

#### DESCRIPTION
<!-- Describe the changes in detail -->
Changes how `MimeTypes` objects are used and initialized in ranger and rifle. In both use cases, the same set of
mimetype files are read and added on top of the hardcoded defaults in the mimetypes python library:

1. Mimetype files set in system (python/mimetypes library installation)
2. The `data/mime.types` from ranger (standalone rifle remains exception here)
3. The `~/.mime.types` if it exists

#### MOTIVATION AND CONTEXT
<!-- Why are these changes required? -->
<!-- What problems do these changes solve? -->
<!-- Link to relevant issues -->

This fixes issue #1744 (on my system at least).

The discussion in #1744 seems to suggest that mimetypes behavior varies across some variables (python version and/or
library versions and/or other system specs). So I guess in some configurations these changes can lead to loading the
same mimetype file multiple times, which is fine.

#### TESTING
<!-- What tests have been run? -->
<!-- How does the changes affect other areas of the codebase? -->

    @staticmethod

title: Hashlib requires objects implementing the buffer API
body:
The hashes from python's hashlib only support objects that implement the
buffer API. Bytes objects (python 2 string, python 3 string.encode())
are such objects.

Passing fields from a stat object to a hash directly caused crashes
whenever ranger checked for an image preview.

Fixes #2032

body: 😬  This causes crashes whenever the code paths come up.

title: Gracefully fallback when file(1) is not available to identify mime-type
body:
<!-- Provide a descriptive summary of the changes in the title above -->

#### ISSUE TYPE
<!-- Pick relevant types and delete the rest -->
- Improvement
When I was running `ranger` in an embedded device (a NAS) with ssh, I was trying to edit something and it keeps refusing to open some files. After checking the log, I found the following:

```sh
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/volume1/main/home/soraxas/git-repo/ranger/ranger/core/actions.py", line 271, in execute_console
    cmd.execute()
  File "/volume1/main/home/soraxas/git-repo/ranger/ranger/config/commands.py", line 1144, in execute
    self.fm.execute_file([File(listpath)], app='editor')
  File "/volume1/main/home/soraxas/git-repo/ranger/ranger/core/actions.py", line 465, in execute_file
    return execute()
  File "/volume1/main/home/soraxas/git-repo/ranger/ranger/core/actions.py", line 463, in execute
    return self.rifle.execute(filenames, mode, label, flags, None)
  File "/volume1/main/home/soraxas/git-repo/ranger/ranger/ext/rifle.py", line 332, in execute
    for count, cmd, lbl, flgs in self.list_commands(files, mimetype):
  File "/volume1/main/home/soraxas/git-repo/ranger/ranger/ext/rifle.py", line 303, in list_commands
    if not self._eval_condition(test, files, None):
  File "/volume1/main/home/soraxas/git-repo/ranger/ranger/ext/rifle.py", line 187, in _eval_condition
    return self._eval_condition2(condition, files, label)
  File "/volume1/main/home/soraxas/git-repo/ranger/ranger/ext/rifle.py", line 217, in _eval_condition2
    return bool(re.search(argument, self.get_mimetype(files[0])))
  File "/volume1/main/home/soraxas/git-repo/ranger/ranger/ext/rifle.py", line 261, in get_mimetype
    process = Popen(["file", "--mime-type", "-Lb", fname], stdout=PIPE, stderr=PIPE)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/subprocess.py", line 711, in __init__
    errread, errwrite)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/subprocess.py", line 1343, in _execute_child
    raise child_exception
OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory
```

It turns out it's because of this line
```python
process = Popen(["file", "--mime-type", "-Lb", fname], stdout=PIPE, stderr=PIPE)
```
where my NAS does not has `file` installed (i.e. `which file` exit with error). I saw that the code had the try/catch block around the Popen `mimetype` line, but not with `file`. I guess it was assumed that `file` will always be available on a system, but I think that was not true on NAS device.

#### DESCRIPTION

After extending the try/catch block around the whole **Popen** and adding the fallback as plaintext (I think it's a very reasonable fallback and is the best that you can do without `file` and `mimetype`), I was able to edit files and use `:bulkrename` with vim without any issues.

- [x] All changes follow the code style **[REQUIRED]**
- [x] All new and existing tests pass **[REQUIRED]**

title: Webp images not considered as images by the internal sxiv/feh/imv hack anymore
body:
#### Runtime Environment
- Operating system and version: Gentoo
- Terminal emulator and version: st
- Python version: 3.7.7 (default, May  3 2020, 20:21:23) [GCC 9.3.0]
- Ranger version/commit: 1.9.2
- Locale: en_US.UTF-8

#### Current Behavior
When trying to browse the pictures of a directory, only the JPG and PNG files are picked up by the sxiv hack (you know, even when opening a single file, open all the neighbours and set position so you can browse the whole directory), WEBP aren't picked anymore.
#### Expected Behavior
WEBP pictures are considered as pictures.
#### Context
Gentoo updating the default Python from 3.6 to 3.7 brought this.

#### Possible Solutions
```
import mimetypes

print(mimetypes.guess_type("hello.webp", False))
mime = mimetypes.MimeTypes()
print(mime.guess_type("hello.webp", False))
```
On this system at least, this fails with both Python 3.7 and 3.8. And ranger instantiates mimetypes in the same way. Still don't know why it fails, though; might (should) be a 3.6 -> 3.7 problem.

- Terminal emulator and version: 
 ```
rxvt-unicode (urxvt) v9.22 - released: 2016-01-23
options: perl,xft,styles,combining,blink,iso14755,unicode3,encodings=eu+vn+jp+jp-ext+kr+zh+zh-ext,fade,transparent,tint,XIM,frills,selectionscrolling,wheel,slipwheel,cursorBlink,pointerBlank,scrollbars=plain+rxvt+NeXT+xterm
```
- Python version: `Python 3.8.1`
- Ranger version/commit: `v1.9.3-18-g081e7315` (output of `git describe HEAD`)
- Locale: `en_US.UTF-8`

#### CHECKLIST
<!-- All [REQUIRED] requisites need to be fulfilled -->
<!-- Replace [ ] with [X] when fulfilled -->
- [x] The `CONTRIBUTING` document has been read **[REQUIRED]**
- [x] All changes follow the code style **[REQUIRED]**
  (`make test_py` outputs is the same before and after the change)
- [x] All new and existing tests pass **[REQUIRED]**
  (`make test_py` output is the same before and after the change)
- [ ] Changes require config files to be updated
    - [ ] Config files have been updated
- [ ] Changes require documentation to be updated
    - [ ] Documentation has been updated
- [ ] Changes require tests to be updated
    - [ ] Tests have been updated

#### DESCRIPTION
<!-- Describe the changes in detail -->
The `execute()` method of the trash command (in `ranger/config/commands.py`)
used to pass a list of file paths (as strings) to `fm.execute_file()`.
The documentation of the `execute_file()` method states that the 'files'
parameter must not be a list of strings:
>     [...]
>     files: a list of file objects (not strings!)
>     [...]
So I changed `files` to be a list of `File` objects and that seems to fix the issue.

*Note: I'm not sure if I need to pass any additional parameters to the `File` constructor.
Passing just the path seemed to work fine in my tests.*
(I'm talking about [this](https://github.com/5hir0kur0/ranger/commit/f65e6f08bcf63b7d915d2a2e98d1f6f891cd30de#diff-ac22d5c05a75c2e025c82cdfcbf695b1R732) line: `files = [File(name) for name in file_names]`).

#### MOTIVATION AND CONTEXT
<!-- Why are these changes required? -->
<!-- What problems do these changes solve? -->
<!-- Link to relevant issues -->
Relevant issue: #1798


#### TESTING
<!-- What tests have been run? -->
<!-- How does the changes affect other areas of the codebase? -->

I ran `make test_py` as I only changed a python file.

title: BAT_STYLE environment variable clashes with bat

labels.name: doc-issue
labels.description: Issues with the docs (manpage/`?c`/wiki),  including errors, absence and improvement suggestions

body:
#### Runtime Environment
- Operating system and version: openSUSE Tumbleweed on snapshot 20200218
- Terminal emulator and version: Konsole 19.12.2
- Python version: 3.7.3
- Ranger version/commit: 1.9.3
- Locale: en_US.UTF-8

#### Current Behavior
Whenever setting `BAT_STYLE` to one of the themes from `bat --list-themes` as described in the [documentation](https://github.com/ranger/ranger/blob/b032a10e487927e6a8b5f5340d9b76ebefa22a18/doc/ranger.1#L1873-L1876), `ranger` cannot preview files.

#### Expected Behavior
Be able to preview files.

#### Context
This issue is preventing me from setting a theme to use whenever previewing files with `bat` within `ranger`. 

#### Possible Solutions
Use another environment variable name, such as `BAT_THEME`, so it doesn't clash with `BAT_STYLE` from `bat`. `BAT_STYLE` is already used in `bat` as you can see in the documentation [here](https://github.com/sharkdp/bat/blob/20ba984c6d73e59cfeb315c1d17962a10fc64e9c/assets/manual/bat.1.in#L113-L121).

#### Steps to reproduce
1. Have `bat` and `ranger` installed.
2. Set the environment variable `BAT_STYLE` to `ansi-light` (or another theme from `bat --list-themes`)
3. Run `bat some_file.txt` and see the error `[bat error]: Unknown style 'ansi-light'`
4. In `ranger`, just try to preview a file and it won't work.
5. Running `unset BAT_STYLE` fixes both issues from steps 3 and 4.

title: The current directory is not readable when using a light theme.
body:
#### Runtime Environment
ranger version: ranger 1.9.2
Python version: 3.8.1 (default, Dec 21 2019, 20:57:38) [GCC 9.2.0]
Locale: None.None
OS: Arch Linux
Terminal: Termite v15, Alacritty is affected too.

#### Current Behavior
When one uses a light theme in the Termite some text (current folder on top) appears as white on white background.

#### Expected Behavior
Text is rendered properly: black on white.

#### Context
The desired behaviour is achieved when I use xterm. I believe, that the issue has something to do with the default background of a terminal emulator, since Termite and Alacritty are dark by default and xterm is light.

#### Possible Solutions
Workaraounds, that users may use now:
- Swap black and white in the Termite settings. Works poor, since other programms, such as neovim, expect that black (color 0) is actually black.
- `export TERM=xterm`

I see a global setting to hint ranger what color background is as a proper solution.

#### Steps to reproduce
1. Open ranger in Termite or Alacritty while using light theme.
2. See that the current directory is not readable.

title: Pass surrogates when listing files for bulkrename
body:
Surrogates aren't allowed in the UTF-8 encoding but filenames can
contain any bytes. We need to pass the surrogates literally because
otherwise `mv` won't be renaming the right files.

title: Make setlocal path=... argument a regex again
body:
#### ISSUE TYPE
<!-- Pick relevant types and delete the rest -->
- Bug fix

#### CHECKLIST
<!-- All [REQUIRED] requisites need to be fulfilled -->
<!-- Replace [ ] with [X] when fulfilled -->
- [x] The `CONTRIBUTING` document has been read **[REQUIRED]**
- [x] All changes follow the code style **[REQUIRED]**
- [x] All new and existing tests pass **[REQUIRED]**
- [ ] Changes require config files to be updated
    - [ ] Config files have been updated
- [ ] Changes require documentation to be updated
    - [ ] Documentation has been updated
- [ ] Changes require tests to be updated
    - [ ] Tests have been updated


From the `setlocal` section of the man page:
```
path is a regular expression.  This means that "path=~/dl" applies to
all paths that start with ~/dl, e.g. ~/dl2 and ~/dl/foo. To avoid
this, use "path=~/dl$".

```
#1652 caused the `path` argument to be regex escaped. This commit
fixes that.

- Terminal emulator and version: iTerm2 3.3
- Python version: 3.6.8 installed by pyenv
- Ranger version/commit: 1.9.2
- Locale: en_US.UTF-8

#### Current Behavior
`ranger` installed by `pip3 install ranger-fm` doesn't work with iTerm2 image preview. A placeholder image is displayed but not the real image.

After removing the `pip3` installed `ranger` and reinstalled it with Homebrew, the problem disappeared.

The shebang of `ranger` from the brew installed one is `#!/usr/bin/python -O` (python 2). I could reproduce the problem by changing it to `#!/usr/local/bin/python3 -O`.

~~The reason I tried to use `ranger` with Python 3 is that, the keybindings from the wiki for tmux integration doesn't work Python 2.~~

~~Error `'module' object has no attribute 'quote'` occurred on Python 2, which is already reported by #1335~~

**Update**: the tmux integration is solved.

title: Tests are silently failing!
body:
#### Runtime Environment
- Operating system and version: Gentoo Linux, x86_64
- Terminal emulator and version: N/A
- Python version: 3.6.5
- Ranger version/commit: cab56031
- Locale: en_US.utf8

#### Current Behavior

`make test` contains this part:

```
**********************************************************************
File "ranger/ext/human_readable.py", line 12, in __main__.human_readable
Failed example:
    human_readable(54)
Exception raised:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/doctest.py", line 1330, in __run
        compileflags, 1), test.globs)
      File "<doctest __main__.human_readable[0]>", line 1, in <module>
        human_readable(54)
      File "ranger/ext/human_readable.py", line 24, in human_readable
        if SettingsAware.settings.size_in_bytes:
    AttributeError: type object 'SettingsAware' has no attribute 'settings'
**********************************************************************
File "ranger/ext/human_readable.py", line 14, in __main__.human_readable
Failed example:
    human_readable(1500)
Exception raised:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/doctest.py", line 1330, in __run
        compileflags, 1), test.globs)
      File "<doctest __main__.human_readable[1]>", line 1, in <module>
        human_readable(1500)
      File "ranger/ext/human_readable.py", line 24, in human_readable
        if SettingsAware.settings.size_in_bytes:
    AttributeError: type object 'SettingsAware' has no attribute 'settings'
**********************************************************************
File "ranger/ext/human_readable.py", line 16, in __main__.human_readable
Failed example:
    human_readable(2 ** 20 * 1023)
Exception raised:
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/doctest.py", line 1330, in __run
        compileflags, 1), test.globs)
      File "<doctest __main__.human_readable[2]>", line 1, in <module>
        human_readable(2 ** 20 * 1023)
      File "ranger/ext/human_readable.py", line 24, in human_readable
        if SettingsAware.settings.size_in_bytes:
    AttributeError: type object 'SettingsAware' has no attribute 'settings'
**********************************************************************
1 items had failures:
   3 of   3 in __main__.human_readable
***Test Failed*** 3 failures.
```

**and** we don't get notified about it when running `make test` and it's affecting Travis CI.

#### Expected Behavior

If a test (doctest in this case) is failing, `make test` should at the very least exit with a non-zero exit code.

#### Context

This problem in particular is caused by [SettingsAware.setting](https://github.com/ranger/ranger/blob/6549b810ae108325fd1bf2634e10884c55413bc8/ranger/ext/human_readable.py#L24) being [assigned](https://github.com/ranger/ranger/blob/a807090fd7d3b21b26d05baf962b6d6a0d615f92/ranger/core/main.py#L90) only during the ranger startup procedure and it doesn't exist when we're running this test.

The bug was seemingly introduced in 6549b810ae108325fd1bf2634e10884c55413bc8 but it's just the tip of the iceberg: such tests would silently fail either way.

#### Possible Solutions

As this is basically a 3-in-1 issue, we need to:

- [x] fix the `size_in_bytes` support in `human_readable.py` during the testing either by making it no longer needed or making the settings available there
- [x] **make our test fail properly**
- [ ] possibly make the settings accessible during the testing (should fix number 1 actually)

#### Steps to reproduce

Run `make test` on a current `master` branch or check the Travis CI output.

title: Ranger enters busy-loop if STDIN file descriptor is closed

labels.name: next-release
labels.description: Wants to be included in the next release

body:
I hope this will solve an old heisenbug. It doesn't seem to always reproduce naturally, but can be provoked using gdb. 

Potentially related, unresolved bug reports: 
- https://github.com/ranger/ranger/issues/87
- https://github.com/ranger/ranger/issues/525


#### Runtime Environment
- Operating system and version: Ubuntu 18.04.1 LTS
- Terminal emulator and version: rxvt-unicode (urxvt) v9.22 - released: 2016-01-23
- ranger version: ranger-master v1.9.2-53-ge56c74bb
- Python version: 2.7.15rc1 (default, Apr 15 2018, 21:51:34) [GCC 7.3.0]
- Locale: None.None
- Shell: GNU bash, version 4.4.19(1)-release (x86_64-pc-linux-gnu)

#### Current Behavior

Ranger enters a busy-loop if STDIN is closed. 

#### Expected Behavior

Ranger exits if STDIN is closed. 


#### Background

Using ranger extensively, I occasionally notice that a ranger process is using 100% of the CPU. 

It is not uncommon for me to start ranger, navigate to a directory, spawn a shell to run a command and restart ranger again. 
I also usually close terminal windows using the window manager, rather than exiting each subprocess running in that window. 

#### Analysis

To the best of my understanding, this is how the bug manifests. 

When a shell exits (e.g. when closing a terminal), it sends a SIGHUP signal to its child processes. 
If the child process does not explicitly handle this signal (which ranger doesn't do), the default behavior is to terminate the process. 

When ranger spawns a shell which restarts ranger, the SIGHUP reaches the first ranger process, but not (always?) the second process (due to the fork-exec?). The terminal and the first ranger process exit, and the remaining ranger process continues to run, but becomes orphaned and adopted by init (pid 1). 

Ranger runs a 'while True' loop which repeatedly wait for user input, which happens here: https://github.com/ranger/ranger/blob/e56c74bb30ad2f363280e4d1a14bf2c20dff5b5f/ranger/gui/ui.py#L239

	key = self.win.getch()

https://docs.python.org/2/library/curses.html#curses.window.getch

If there is no input, getch() waits for some time, then returns -1. However, because the STDIN file descriptor was closed by the earlier exited processes, getch() presumably throws an error and returns -1 immediately, which causes ranger to enter a continuous busy-loop. 


#### Possible Solutions

If getch() returns -1 and os.isatty(0) returns False, ranger should exit. 

#### Steps to reproduce

##### Natural way (not guaranteed to work)

In a terminal, start ranger: 

  > ranger

Press 'S' to spawn a shell
Start ranger again:

  > ranger

(Maybe press down a couple of times)
Close the terminal (e.g. Alt-F4)

The former ranger process exits, but the latter enters a busy-loop. 

##### gdb way

Force-close the STDIN file descriptor of a running ranger process

Start ranger
Attach to process with gdb: 

  > gdb -p PID_OF_RANGER

Close fd 0:

  > (gdb) p close(0)

Detach to let ranger keep running:

  > (gdb) detach

Ranger enters busy-loop.

body:
#### ISSUE TYPE

- Python version: python 3.4.5 [GCC 4.9.4]
- Ranger version/commit: ranger-master 1.9.0b5 20f0f2ba96a4a9dcbb8beffbee957b42157d4efd
- Locale: en_US.utf8

#### EXPECTED BEHAVIOR
The image preview should remain intact, no matter what I do.

#### CURRENT BEHAVIOR
When I press shift in st, the image preview disappears.
If I revisit the image, the image preview reappears until I press shift or any other key.
The image preview disappears after a few seconds automatically.
It also disappears if I shift the focus to another window.

#### POSSIBLE SOLUTIONS
It doesn't happen in uxterm, but uxterm doesn't support fontconfig which st supports well.
I must have proper fontconfig support to read chinese characters in ranger.

I could use urxvt, but urxvt doesn't support fontconfig properly.

title: rc.conf: use the correct confpath for scope.sh
body:
Change the default rc.conf to look inside $XDG_CONFIG_HOME rather than ~/.config, as required by the XDG Base Directory specification.

#### ISSUE TYPE
- Bug fix

#### CHECKLIST
- [X] The `CONTRIBUTING` document has been read **[REQUIRED]**
- [X] All changes follow the code style **[REQUIRED]**
- [X] All new and existing tests pass **[REQUIRED]**
- [X] Changes require config files to be updated
    - [X] Config files have been updated
- [ ] Changes require documentation to be updated
    - [ ] Documentation has been updated
- [ ] Changes require tests to be updated
    - [ ] Tests have been updated

#### DESCRIPTION

The change is implemented with the line ```eval cmd("set preview_script " + fm.confpath("scope.sh"))```. This re-uses the fm.confpath function to guarantee that we’re using the same path as `ranger --copy-config`, which is the desired behavior.

#### MOTIVATION AND CONTEXT

This fixes #849; see the issue for details.

title: Incorrect cursor movement in console for long text at the ends
body:
#### ISSUE TYPE
- Bug report

#### RUNTIME ENVIRONMENT
<!-- Retrieve Python/ranger version and locale with `ranger -\-version` -->
- Operating system and version: Arch Linux
- Terminal emulator and version: Termite 12-1
- Python version: ranger-master 1.9.0b5
- Ranger version/commit: ranger-master 1.9.0b5
- Locale: ranger-master 1.9.0b5

#### EXPECTED BEHAVIOR
When editing long text in the console (such as when renaming a file with a name exceeding the terminal's width), I expect cursor movement to correspond to the keys pressed, like, pressing `<left>` should result in the cursor moving by one column to the left.  If necessary, scrolling should happen to display the rest of the text.

#### CURRENT BEHAVIOR
With long text, movement at the ends does *not* happen.  If I'm at the rightmost position and hit `<left>`, I don't see the cursor move, however insertion of text adds a character at that position.  After moving a sufficient amount to the left, hitting `<left>` results in the expected cursor movement.  The exact amount of text to move beyond appears to depend on how much longer the console contents are than the terminal's width.

#### CONTEXT
Renaming files with long names is rather annoying as I can't easily move to the problematic part and edit it due to the lack of visual feedback.  Blindly editing text without cursor at the position it should be is error-prone and tedious.

#### POSSIBLE SOLUTIONS
I'm not sure how this should be fixed.  It could be something as fundamental as the underlying ncurses widget not supporting text wrapping.  I'd need to look into how this whole thing works before making a proper suggestion.

#### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
1. Visit file with a name longer than the terminal width
2. Hit `A`, then `<left>` to navigate one column before the end
3. See the cursor stay in place.

title: Hardcoded incorrect path to scope.sh
body:
Ranger always looks for scope.sh inside ~/.config/ranger ([responsible line](https://github.com/ranger/ranger/blob/ad58add9e0e6cb4675b231d967ff2204eabad4c3/ranger/config/rc.conf#L46)). This is incorrect: ranger should instead look inside [$XDG_CONFIG_HOME](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/basedir-spec/basedir-spec-0.7.html)/ranger.

This is aggravated by the fact that `ranger --copy-config=scope` will (correctly) copy scope.sh to $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/ranger. One would imagine that ranger would be able to find config files it itself created.

#### ISSUE TYPE
- Bug report

#### RUNTIME ENVIRONMENT
- Operating system and version: Arch Linux 4.9.6-1
- Terminal emulator and version: irrelevant; the issue can be reproduced even when ranger isn’t attached to a pty.
- Python version: Python 3.6.0 (default, Jan 16 2017, 12:12:55)
- Ranger version/commit: reproduced on both ranger-stable 1.8.1 and current master (30553796)
- Locale: LANG=en_US.UTF-8, LC_COLLATE=C

#### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
1. `export XDG_CONFIG_HOME=~/not-the-default`
2. `ranger --copy-config=scope`
3. `strace -f ranger 2>&1 | grep scope.sh`

#### EXPECTED BEHAVIOR
Ranger opens and uses $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/ranger/scope.sh:

    stat("~/not-the-default/ranger/scope.sh", ...) = 0

#### CURRENT BEHAVIOR
Ranger looks for ~/.config/ranger/scope.sh and fails if it doesn’t exist:

    stat("~/.config/ranger/scope.sh", ...) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)

#### CONTEXT

This issue prevents image previews from working. As a workaround, I created the directories ~/.config and ~/.config/ranger and copied my scope.sh in there; this lets image previews work, but is obviously not a proper solution.

#### POSSIBLE SOLUTIONS
Just change [this line](https://github.com/ranger/ranger/blob/ad58add9e0e6cb4675b231d967ff2204eabad4c3/ranger/config/rc.conf#L46) to use $XDG_CONFIG_HOME instead of hard-coding .config.

title: Sort hex numbers
body:
#### ISSUE TYPE
- Bug report (potential)

#### RUNTIME ENVIRONMENT
ranger-stable 1.8.1
Python 3.6.0 (default, Jan 16 2017, 12:12:55)
[GCC 6.3.1 20170109]

#### EXPECTED BEHAVIOR
Filenames named in hexcodes must be monotonous ascending in natural sort

#### CURRENT BEHAVIOR
Order is decided by filename prefix part which resembles number and the rest of filename is ignored:
```
7f838000
7fff7000
00400000
0057a000
00584000
72bae000
72baf000
72dae000
72daf000
72fae000
72faf000
729ae000
729af000
73bae000
```

#### CONTEXT
* irritating to switch to basename sort each time
* often forget to do this and therefore mess relative order when analysing dumps

#### POSSIBLE SOLUTIONS
For natural sort take into account if filename contains non-digits and then treat whole filename as text.
And only if filename contains digits only -- then treat filename as number when sorting.
Current natural sort behavior seems to decide number/text by filename prefix only, which is wrong.

#### STEPS TO REPRODUCE
Copy filelist in 'current behaviour' then touch them:
$ xsel -ob | xargs touch

title: Crash on invocation of alias with tab char
body:
<!-- Provide a descriptive summary of the issue in the title above -->

#### EXPECTED BEHAVIOR

Tab and space separation should be interpreted the same in `rc.conf`,
or at least tabs should not ungracefully crash ranger.


#### CURRENT BEHAVIOR
<!-- Bug: How is it different from the expected behavior? -->
The following lines in rc.conf crash ranger when triggered (by pressing F):

alias filter	scout -flprst
map F console filter%space

Ranger crashes when filtering the output.

Treat `whitespace` instead of only the `space` character as valid separator.
Or: Catch the exception `KeyError` and give some reasonable output.
Or: Replace all tab chars in the config with spaces before parsing.

title: Macros (like %s) don't work when they used in aliases in rc.conf
body:
So, after the upgrade to ranger-git (1.7.2.406.g496b1c0-1) from the stable (1.7.2-1), I have problems with the macros in my `rc.conf`, for example the `%s` doesn't get converted to the selected filename(s) when used in an alias.

Examples: 

`alias XX shell chmod +x %s` doesn't work: `chmod: cannot access '%s': No such file or directory`
Also tried with `%%s` or with quotes `"%%s"` or `"%s"` but none of them works.

`alias extract shell atool -xe %s` then running the extract on a file: `atool: %s: no such file and cannot identify format from extension`

These commands work fine when they typed in ranger with shell command (hitting  the **s** key) or when they mapped to a key, for example:

`map X shell chmod +x %s`
**or**
`map X shell atool -xe %s`

They work. 

But they don't work when they used in aliases in the rc.conf.

title: Changing sort order causes race condition when chaining
body:
the default `om` binding:

    map om chain set sort=mtime; set sort_reverse=False

and I want `om` to do:

    1. set sort_directories_fisr false
    2. set sort=mtime
    3. set sort_reverse=False
    4. goto the first line of the list

I use `move to=0` as step 4:

    map om chain set sort_directories_first false; set sort=mtime; set sort_reverse=False; move to=0

but this is not working, all the first 3 steps will be executed as expected except step 4, unless I execute `om` again, and I don't why.  And I can do the whole process step by step using those 4 steps in console `:`, and it works as expected.

If I change the step 4 to `console move to=0`, then I have to type `Enter` key to execute it and it works too.

So how can I make the step 4 work, (just one `om` binding will execute the whole 4 steps`)?

title: Tmux title reset
body:
This is a fix for #228 and duplicate #685. The problem is that whenever you set the title, `automatic-rename` gets disabled:
```
            automatic-rename [on | off]
                     Control automatic window renaming.  When this
                     setting is enabled, tmux will rename the window
                     automatically using the format specified by
                     automatic-rename-format.  This flag is automati‐
                     cally disabled for an individual window when a
                     name is specified at creation with new-window or
                     new-session, or later with rename-window, or with
                     a terminal escape sequence.
```

This PR detects the state of the option when ranger starts, and restores this when quiting.

title: Sane setting fallback values
body: Every setting will be initialized with the first allowed value. Alternative to #602.

title: Do not enable line_numbers when it is not set to any value
body: Currently if the option `line_numbers` is not set to any value whatsoever in the config, it gets enabled by default. It's due to checking if it's `!= 'false'` which is true if it's an empty string. It seems `settings.ALLOWED_VALUES` is not enforced anywhere so I've added a helper function that checks for it and added it to these value comparisons. I do not consider it a final solution (manually calling `valid_value()` is ugly and still prone to bugs) but it's a good start.

title: Using tabs with folders with katakana name causes the tab name to have random gaps in it
body:
This is a pretty minor issue, but still. 
Using tabs and entering a folder with title in katakana (it likely happens with other characters from non latin scripts too though i haven't tried it), the tab title's background color is not uniform.

This can be reproduced easily by naming a folder, for example, "キャラクター" (katakana for "character") and noting that ![this](http://puu.sh/phM2A/d4ccfdb999.png) this happens. In short, there's a random interruption in the green background when the tab with katakana name is selected. Having the second tab in katakana or in english changes the place in which the small gap appears, so it's probably character independent. For example if i use two folders with the same name as above, the gap will appears before タ.

It's also worth noting that the second folder's full name is "Various", not "Variou", however the last letter is pushed out of the terminal, likely because of the empty gap between キ and ャ.

I'm using the latest source and Arch Linux, and this is not a problem related to my fonts as I've reproduced this bug on a different laptop and with different fonts. Terminal is rxvt-unicode.

title: Tab completion does not take %macros into account
body: The tab completion provided by `Command._tab_directory_content` may create an invalid completion if the file contains %-s which would be then interpreted as macros. Of course it applies only to the commands that resolve macros.

title: Setuptools breaks ". ranger" shortcut
body:
Ranger allows you to type `. ranger` in bash to magically activate automatic directory switching like in https://github.com/hut/ranger/blob/master/examples/bash_automatic_cd.sh by running a polyglot bash script in the `ranger.py` executable, see also https://github.com/hut/ranger/blob/master/ranger.py . However, since 8b958c577a7f5f484db42b7c26b0340e14fd9351 this doesn't work when setuptools is present, because it installs a custom script rather than taking the original ranger script.

 see also: #252

title: Don't display Git status as "good" if status is unknown
body:
I'm using [etckeeper](https://etckeeper.branchable.com/) to keep track of /etc. This means that all of /etc is under Git "control", but /etc/.git is readable only by root (and I don't run `ranger` as uid 1). ranger currently shows all files under /etc as `√` (though /etc itself is shown as `√?`), even though ranger really doesn't have any idea about the status of the files (verified by it showing this "good" status for ignored and changed files too).

I would suggest that either it shows `√?` or `?` (to indicate that its a Git/VCS directory, but status isn't known) or nothing at all.

title: `:bulkrename` doesn't work with `:flat -1`
body: When flattening subdirectories with `:flat`, the filenames in `:bulkrename` are only basenames rather than having their relative path prepended. That way, `mv` can't find the files and the command fails.

title: Ranger attempts to preview binary files
body:
With scope.sh disabled, ranger attempts to preview .odt and .apk files even though they are binary.  The effect is that the preview pane is opened (if it was collapsed before), but it stays blank, no preview is displayed.

In this snippet, the first file does not provoke a preview whereas the second does.
https://gist.github.com/SammysHP/764fcd3d1c474bd49645

title: copy&pasting doesn't copy links
body: For whatever reason, copying with yy and pasting with pp will simply ignore any symlinks in the source directory.

title: Unable to map Alt+SpecialChar
body:
I have the following mappings in my rc:

```
map <a-!>     tab_open 1
map <a-@>     tab_open 2
map <a-#>     tab_open 3
map <a-$>     tab_open 4
map <a-%>     tab_open 5
map <a-^>     tab_open 6
map <a-&>     tab_open 7
map <a-*>     tab_open 8
map <a-(>     tab_open 9
```

Unfortunately none of them work.

Note that my keyboard has the number row inverted, ie I have to press shift to get the numbers, else I get the special chars. Pressing Alt+Shift+!, Alt+Shift+@, etc, does switch tabs to 1, 2, etc.

I also tried mapping <a-=>, <a->, etc with no results.

Ranger: ranger-master 1.6.1 (git HEAD at the time of writing)
Urxvt: rxvt-unicode (urxvt) v9.19 - released: 2013-10-27

title: renaming breaks with insufficient permissions
body: when renaming a directory with :rename and you don't have sufficient permissions, the preview disappears.

title: File highlighting does not get updated when file changes
body:
Select a file with space and move the cursor away. Change the 'executable' flag with '-ax' or '+ax' and unselect with 'uv'. If the file had executable highlighting, it will remain until you move the cursor on it and vice versa.

I guess the highlighting does not get updated when the selection changes. Would be nice to fix this, thanks!

title: Python process using high CPU
body:
I don't understand why the python process are still running after opening a shell at a directory, shouldn't ranger just cd and quit itself?

That's my first impression when I figured that the Python process out of no where is from ranger after opening some shells from ranger.

After doing a small research I found out ranger spawns the shell, but not only I don't know how to resume ranger from the shell, I can't quit ranger easily, and what happen is that Python process would go crazy and uses 100% of CPU of some sort, and I have to go to activity monitor to force quit those Python processes, which would destroy everything, all the shell I have opened from ranger. This is very annoying.

Am I doing it wrong? Or is this some serious bug?

Until this bug is fixed, I don't know if I could still use ranger as directory jumper now :(
